body:
Hello, I would like to share my understandings about the issue.
I tired to replicate the mentioned bug by calling `test_check_soft_dependencies_raises_error()` function from
`/sktime/utils/_testing/tests/test_check_imports.py`

The message received :
No module named 'unavailable_module'. 'unavailable_module' is a soft dependency and not included in the sktime installation. Please run: `pip install unavailable_module`. To install all soft dependencies, run: `pip install sktime[all_extras]`

I don't understand what you mean by `folder_name` ?
The message simply asks to pip install the package name (string) passed as argument in `_check_soft_dependencies(*packages)`
from `/sktime/utils/validation/_dependencies.py`

I would like to understand more on:
1. What's difference between `pypi_name` and `folder_name` ?
Because as per my understanding, if we pass the pypi_name when calling `_check_soft_dependencies("pypi_name")` we will get the required recommendation.
2. Where are we using `_check_soft_dependencies("folder_name")` (if possible)? and can we simply achieve the goal by using "pypi_name" instead of "folder_name" while calling the _check_soft_dependencies ?


PS: I'm new to open source (would like to start my journey from this issue) and this is my first ever comment on github. So let me know if I am violating any code of conduct or if I am thinking in completely wrong direction. Thanks.

Welcome, @the-prof-paradox!

Sorry for lack of detail in the original post.

The crucial example in this case would be the `dtw-python` package, which is distinct from the `dtw` package.
`sktime` has a soft dependency on `dtw-python` (for alignment algorithms), but not on `dtw`.

Both packages, once installed, require one to write `import dtw.stuff`, since the package folder name for both is `dtw`.

The error message should say "please `pip install dtw-python`, if `dtw-python` is not installed and a user wants to use the dependent estimator `AlignerDTW`. But it does say "please `pip install dtw`", which is the wrong package.
I´ve added minimal example and actual vs expected behaviour to the original post now, thanks for pointing this out.
PS: simply changing the line to `_check_soft_dependencies("dtw-python")` does not work, since a check is done in the function by whether `import package_name` works.

Thanks for the clarifications!

I would like to fix this issue so if there are no other asignees can you assign it to me?

Hi @fkiraly 
How about we store the pypi packages name of the libraries in a dictionary like this:
```
_PYPI_PACKAGES = {
    "dtw":"dtw-python"
}
in the format:
dict = {
    "folder-name" : "pypi-name"
}
```
inside the `sktime/sktime/utils/validation/_dependencies.py` where `_check_soft_dependencies(*packages)` is defined.

because we need to map the folder-names to their PYPI names while recommending the pip install message.

I tried to dive deeper into code base and found that in `sktime/build_tools/azure/check_soft_dependencies.py` we have a `SOFT_DEPENDENCIES` dictionary. So I was thinking if we make the _PYPI_PACKAGES dictionary for each soft dependency mentioned here.

Then we will have all the correct pairs of pypi-name and folder-name in a dictionary and in the message we can print `"pip install {_PYPI_PACKAGES[package]}"` if it exists else simply print "pip install {package}"

The list of all the soft dependencies I could find is: 
```
[
'dtw',
 'esig',
 'fbprophet',
 'hcrystalball',
 'matplotlib',
 'pmdarima',
 'stumpy',
 'tbats',
 'tsfresh'
]
```


Now, I would like to know:

1. Is this approach fine? 
2. If yes, then are there more soft dependencies with name conflicts like dtw and dtw-python? I manually tried to search for all the above mentioned soft dependencies on pypi.org and all looked like they won't have such conflicts except for `tsfresh` and `tsfresh-ppi` (just in case but tsfresh-ppi doesn't look relevant).
3. Are there more soft dependencies apart from the ones mentioned above?

> Is this approach fine?

I would see this only as a last resort if this cannot be inferred from the packages themselves somehow.

The main downside of this is that someone needs to *know* and *remember* that we've done this, and regularly check.
And any extender needs to be aware that this is happening - soft dependencies are added relatively frequently.

Generally, a solution that does not add to the maintenance, extension, and release process would be far preferred.

Surely this should be possible to automate somehow? (not sure though how)

> re there more soft dependencies apart from the ones mentioned above?

All should be there listed in the `all_extras` requirements, in `pyproject.toml`. I think there are more than those you listed.

I don't think there is a way of getting the top level module name from a package name without installing or at least downloading the package itself. The information is usually in `setup.py` like in the case of `dtw-python` https://github.com/DynamicTimeWarping/dtw-python/blob/81f26e1e052ef781d729e549fcd5e2b401e68af8/setup.py#L49 but can be in `pyproject.toml` in pypi or poetry flavors, so the task is not trivial at all. One solution would be to make a trip to pypi.org and download/install the package but that is poor solution since to throw an exception you would need to install a package dynamically. 

To be honest I don't understand the problem being solved here too well. When exactly is the soft dependency checker run? Why would we recommend installing a single package through pip?

> To be honest I don't understand the problem being solved here too well. When exactly is the soft dependency checker run? Why would we recommend installing a single package through pip?

I think when you are trying to import an estimator which uses a soft dependency inside.

>Why would we recommend installing a single package through pip?

"Dear user, if you want to use `MyEstimatorThatInterfacesPackageX`, please first `pip install package_X` which is a soft dependency (and that's the reason you haven't installed it yet when you installed `sktime` without soft dependencies)"

> I don't think there is a way of getting the top level module name from a package name without installing or at least downloading the package itself.

Well, if that's the case, then the `dict` idea is not too bad, it's easy to implement at least and better than the status quo.

I guess we should then make it easily configurable and overridable, with package name being top level module name by default, but you can specify both. Finding a good place for the config of overrides may be tricky.

> so the task is not trivial at all.

it is certainly non-trivial, but it seems so extremely generic that surely some good solutions must exist for it?

issue.title: [ENH] allow different import and package names in soft dependency check

labels.name: maintenance
labels.description: Continuous integration, unit testing & package distribution

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR solves https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/1906 by adding an option to specify a package name different from an import name directly in `_check_soft_dependencies`.

This is then used to address the issue with the `dtw-python` import (whose import name is `dtw`, but package name is `dtw-python`).

This PR also adds:
* a missing soft dependency check in the same module
* input checks to `_check_soft_dependencies`
* the option to pass a class or string to pass information on the object, class, or module requiring the import to the error message generation logic

body:
@the-prof-paradox, I assume your self-unassignment means you no longer wanted to work on this.

I have solved the issue now by adding an argument to the soft dependencies check function, #2545.
